pros: Definitely an opportunity to network and meet many incredibly intelligent people. If you do your homework and understand the compensation department it is easy to move up in the organization quickly.
cons:
While a pro is to easy move up the ladder if you know the system, it is also very easy to get stuck in a dead-end position if you are not actively attempting to move up. It is very rare for someone to get promoted in a department. The only way to move-up is to move to different departments (which is disappointing). 

The area is a very difficult area to live in if you're a young, single person. Many of the events hosted by the hospital are catered towards an older demographic (quilting/knitting/stamping). If you are an older person with a partner/family who doesn't tend to do anything exciting, this is the place for you. 

For a healthcare organization, it doesn't have the best healthcare. And the benefits are average at best. The earned time is nice for taking time off but you have to "earn" the time to get paid for a holiday.

pros:
Good work environment and 
positive culture and great supervisors
cons: not so much flexible with work from home

review_title: I started my journey with DH as a child, as I grew I dreamed of giving back the amazing care I had received, and I did!
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Concord, NH
pros: Great reputation, Great team of healthcare workers, Very nice time-off/Earned time package, discounts on cell phone services among other discounts offered
cons: Benefits are decreasing due to cost cuts, "perks" have been taken away, promotions are few and far between as well as raises-hard to receive any increase in wages, even with outstanding reviews

pros: Some of the most talented and dedicated healthcare professionals in the world work here, and devotion to the patients is genuine among the clinicians and support personnel.  It is a privilege to work alongside such people.
cons: "Leadership" is rarely cultivated and promoted from within. Officers and directors are imported, glorified consultants at exorbitant "competitive" salaries and severance packages, many of whom do not even bother to purchase or rent in the area.  Sole devotion seems to be to getting the green Dartmouth star on the resume and moving on. Employees are considered easily expendable and replaced. Nationally- and globally-recognized experts in all fields are ignored as they walk out the door, or better yet, ignominiously escorted to the door for daring to disagree with whatever ad-hoc decrees issue forth from leadership that week.  Mistakes are often firing offenses, leading predictably to utter institutional paralysis, with everyone terrified of making any substantial decisions.

pros: Day shift, no weekends required.
cons: Lack of support from superiors

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Lebanon, NH
pros: Good benefits and a rewarding company to work for.
cons: Lack of communication from management.

review_title: Cares about employees amidst a pandemic
job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in Lebanon, NH
pros: Great environment to work in all around
cons: Workflow can be sometimes difficult

pros: Very collaborative when it pertains to research.
cons: Multiple administrative shake-ups, which can be disruptive to the function of the department.

pros: Top notch service, collegiality among staff.
cons: No incentivized plan for employees.

pros: Supportive environment most of the time.
cons: Too many layers of management

pros: Everything is amazing and wonderful to work
cons: Long hours around covid patients

pros: There are great pay and benefits
cons: too many layers of management

pros: Great benefits and family atmosphere
cons: Sometimes they keep employees that they shouldn't

pros: Beautiful location; above average place to receive clinical care.
cons: Everything else. Outside of physicians and most nurses, the middle to executive management (including the board of directors) either do not care about the organization or are too stupid to understand how to improve the environment. The morale is horrific. Effective, intelligent employees who want to make a difference and change the current toxic environment are quickly shut up and shut down by middle management who are afraid to lose their jobs if upper level management discovers their incompetence. There is a reason most management is working at DH, in the middle of nowhere, where there is effectively zero competition. Most of these individuals would have a hard time finding employment, much less executive management positions, in any city with more than 75,000 people. Very little opportunity for advancement. Not rewarded for hard work, good ideas or positive impact on co-workers, patients or community. Highly political environment ensures that everyone has a "me-first" attitude, without regard to ethics, morals or laws.

pros: Beautiful facility, wide scope of patient care services and associated job options, generally congenial interactions and mutually supportive staff relationships (excepting a disturbingly large portion of leadership and supervisory personnel).  Working conditions are generally above average and the caliber of the employees is sufficient to continue delivering   high-quality health care services, notwithstanding substantial short-comings in management and leadership priorities.
cons: Leadership and management failing to grasp the value and advantages (both fiscal and functional) of employee satisfaction and retention at all levels.  Long-present pattern of attractive promises without delivery.  Continuing year-over-year increases in leadership compensation and benefits coincident with an insidious devaluation of compensation and benefits to employees.  Comparatively high employee and leadership turnover.

review_title: DH has a great work culture!
pros:
I work at Dartmouth-Hitchcock in Nashua and I cannot say enough about this organization! The community and work culture here is exceptional. Friendly faces in every office and great communication. I enjoy reading our Weekly Reader. It keeps us all up to date on each other's department and what is going on at the headquarters. Employees are thorough in their work and I feel as if we always have each other's backs. Employees are rewarded for their hard work with WOW awards. I think this pushes employees to work hard. Also, patient satisfaction and patient-centered care is VERY important here. I believe this is the way every healthcare facility should be operated and I am appreciative that DH is patient-centered. There is definitely a "Culture of Caring" here are DH. 

Also, we have a BRAND NEW building and it's beautiful. Plus, the hours here are very convenient.
cons: After your yearly review, there is no monetary raise. You have to wait until the annual raise that is distributed throughout the entire organization. The annual percentage does not reflect the cost of living.

job_title: Near the Yellow Brick Road in Lebanon, NH
pros: In this particular region, there is not a lot of options for employment other than this facility. The area is a great place for family and year round entertainment.
cons:
Much like reality television, you will encounter alliances and if you are not onboard you will be voted off the island, period. If you come to this facility without very much experience don't expect to be trained in ANY area where you can learn and grow. However, be prepared to do the lion's share of the work and receive scathing and insulting reviews that come as a total shock. 
Management is disorganized and disengaged which leaves out the basics: distance and direction-this means support! Instead of support expect blame and no recognition of any of YOUR hard work. The concept of "TEAM" does not live here. In fact, the overall vibe is "be thankful you have a job." A very juvenile mentality for sure.
The culture of caring is about the almighty profit upper management strives to reach and rarely achieves. This is not a culture that invests in the people that pull the weight that brings in the dough. 
Imagine a culture that supports, challenges, and motivates their employees. 
Imagine a culture that dissolves arrogance and promotes creativity.

pros: Providers (MD, DO, APRN,PA, RD, RN) are very nice and love their job. I was one of these providers and there is a level of respect amongst this group.
cons: If you are not a part of the "provider" group you are not treated the same. Catered events for the providers but pizza in the break room for the rest (secretaries, medical assistants). Administration including dept managers and senior leadership do not listen to employees when offering suggestions for improvement. Some employees are favored and never get spoken to but others are targeted for termination or discipline for other reasons. Pay is not competitive. Don't be fooled by the name Dartmouth. Care is just as good at Elliot Hospital, Catholic Medical Center, Southern NH Medical Center and Concord Hospital to name a few. Lots of money is raised for CHaD throughout the year but there are many other non-profits that need help in our community. Dunkin Donuts can raise over $80,000 in one day for CHaD. Local animal shelters would love to see just $100 donation. As a former employee I saw how the money was spent but prefer not to say here.

pros: The Aging Resource Center, Dartmouth's senior center, is designed to feel like a home away from home. The employees are a tight knit group and all enjoy what they do - which is helping the older generation age in an easier fashion, including teaching them about medical ailments, providing activities for patients and caretakers, conducting research, holding flu clinics, and being there to spend time with walk-in clients on a daily basis.
cons: The only downside is the constant change in pace. Some days, the center is buzzing with activity and seniors are actively bettering their lives with the help of the staff. Other times, nothing is happening. No clients show up, and the center is extremely dull.

pros: Great location, friendly workforce, academic medical center, healthcare leader, decent compensation, so-so benefits, very good reputation, newer facility,
cons: Very poorly run from an administrative standpoint. Huge gap between C-level and rest of organization.  No clear strategy and no execution plan.  Silos don't communicate nor work well with one another. Dysfunctional management across the board. Extremely poor internal communications. No performance management, No defined career path,and No succession planning.  No management nor leadership training. Known in the community as a "mom and pop" shop, as business processes are extremely immature (ineffective governance, lack of financial controls, lack of corporate standards).

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Administrative Assistant in White River Junction, VT
pros: There are some great people to work with.   There is a good commitment to offering a variety of ways for employees to be as healthy as they can be.
cons: It has become all about money and quite a bit of double talk.   They talk a good line about the commitment to customer service, but the actions of management is strictly about the bottom line.   Because of the rising cost of benefits and lack of pay increases according to the IRS I actually make less than I did when I was hired.

job_title: Certified Clinical Medical Assistant in Lebanon, NH
pros: Working with top notch doctors and residents who are brand new, lots of resources and room to grow.  So many chances of growth because the organization is so large, with hard work, dedication and being responsible, one can move up to their potential a lot quicker than working in a small outfit.
cons: In some departments, long term growth hits a ceiling, but with the organization being so big, the chance to move on and grow can actually happen quickly.

review_title: Central Sterile has a lot to offer employees who want to make a difference in heathcare and job opportunities.
job_title: Central Sterile Tech in Lebanon, NH
pros: It can be very rewarding in job pride.  Being able to use the the facilities in the gym.  It is defineatly fast paced which is great if you like to keep busy.
cons: Management gets in the employees faces and bad mouth the employees, management like to keep the employees at odds with each other.  Management always  looking to cause commotion between workers. Management not on floor enough to acknowledge the going on, so workers are encouraged to bring petty conversations to their attention.

pros:
Great benefits - both healthcare and vacation time
Great co-workers - smart, kind people who care about helping patients
Great work-life balance - very family-friendly
cons:
Salaries are probably lower than average for the market
Path of advancement is quite narrow, especially in IT. While the work is interesting, it is frustrating to feel that you may be in the same position 5-10 years from now even if you do excellent work
HR is a weak spot
Hard to get a good grasp on the prospects of the organization as a whole. Get conflicting messages from leadership/gossip, and don't completely trust senior leaders to be honest

pros: The pay scale is one of the best in the area, across all job groups. They actively solicit feedback from employees about how best to improve. The benefits were pretty good, again, some of the best I've seen in our area.
cons: It is very much a "top-down" organization. Complaints about individuals seemed to go into the ether. In the department I worked in, there were very few chances to advance. If one wanted to advance, you would have to transfer out of our department to another.

review_title: HR: Less fake it, more make it
pros: Co-workers, office hours, most of the Benefits, flexibility, location, travel, large employer, different locations, close to west Lebanon, cafeteria, services
cons: Lack of Management accountability, leadership skills, communication, no thought process needed (pull the trigger and figure it out as we go)

pros: Good coworkers; great technology. The physicians tend to listen to the nursing staff when it comes to the patient. Salary is good for the area. Benefits are also good for the area as well.
cons: They are magnet but the senior leadership doesn't seem to hear the staff many times. They treat the organization like we are only a business at times. Raises don't happen very often even if you get a review which also hasn't been consistent. No oncall but toomany travelers so have to use earn time when called off.

review_title: Once I was a proud DHMC employee.......
pros: The folks who work with patients are wonderfully dedicated. Beautiful area. Best game in town.....
cons: Unbelievably TOP HEAVY!  Arrogance at upper levels makes positive change near impossible. The workers are often doing 2-3 persons jobs, due to lower level personnel cutbacks. Patient care suffers due to low staffing levels. Being told 'you are lucky to have a job" is not inspirational in any way. No raises no retirement match.

pros:
Brand name and Ivy League cachet due to affiliation with Dartmouth Medical School; Level I Trauma Center and only one in this region, so for clinical experience in this area, DHMC is your hands down best bet. CEO seems visionary; ton of talent among the residents and attending physicians, which makes for constant learning opportunities. Nice collaboration between MDs and RNs, with a few exceptions. For a Level I Trauma Center and teaching hospital it has a decidedly community hospital feel, not as cold as other teaching hospitals. 
The place itself is beautiful, lots of light, good art curated by someone in house. There's a fantastic onsite library, the medical school is right there. AWESOME resources in terms of learning.
cons:
Much of the middle management and department heads throughout are insufferable, inexperienced, seem disorganized and unsupported, a lot of management turnover, not always with improvement. They seem to promote from within, which is great on one hand, but not always a good idea (especially with staff/leaders who have no other experience but DHMC, a sort of perpetuation of cultural problems occurs with this, especially in nursing.) Lot of staff turnover as well.
Paltry benefits package, worst health insurance ever, stagnant wages, lost their Magnet nursing status essentially due to poor leadership and disgruntled staff. 

Worst scheduling systems ever, truly. If you weren't pro-union before working here, you may well be on leaving.
They're the only game of their ilk in the area, and they have the Dartmouth name, so there's a certain amount of arrogance in HR and management about this. After all, where else are you going to go in this region? Staff and patients alike are a bit of a "captive audience."
Some of the practice is behind the times, probably due to geographical location. Still I would think being Ivy League, they might be a little more cutting edge. But you can't tell them anything- They're Dartmouth.

pros:
Engaged staff that are willing to work together and are accountable in many different specialties. Providers overall are respectful of staff. Teamwork is the rule not the exception.
Academic medical center that has a local hospital feel. For the area they do pay well and they have worked hard to continue to promote retention of nurses and staff to prevent high turnover.
cons:
Retirement match is not guaranteed. Gets voted on every year. Difficult to be told that you get 12% of a 3% match.
The operating budget is always tenuous due to the amount of traveling nurses they have to keep on. It's not a shock as to why the benefits continue to be cut back.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Bedford, NH
pros:
I work in the Patient Service Center as a Rep. We take calls all day and night until 10:30 pm from Patients and other hospitals needing to speak with our specialists. 
The healthcare providers are generally nice and happy to take pages. Nurses and Medical Assistants have attitude issues when taking calls from patients. 
We do have some down time and it’s not that stressful but sometimes during the day it gets a bit crazy. 
Benefits are the best I have ever seen. Really good amount of paid time off and great insurance.
Supervisors are always willing to help.
cons: The coworkers can be catty even though they themselves are elderly. Environment is not that welcoming to new employees.

review_title: Working as a physician doing administrative work at Dartmouth-Hitchcock
job_title: Professor of Surgery in West Lebanon, NH
pros: Great opportunities, congenial colleagues, good life balance.
cons: Tension in current health care environment about how clinicians should be paid - not specific to Dartmouth-Hitchcock but is a general trend for physicians.  Incentive pays based on RVU's is in many ways at conflict with incentive for working efficiently and perhaps doing less.

pros: good place to gain experience, wonderful area to live, fairly good salary for region, opportunity for advancement if in medical field (if allied health it is much more limited)
cons: Can be very unsupportive, inconsistent policy and practice depending on service and department, cutting positions and roles that seem short-sighted resulting in much heavier workloads and great potential for poorer quality care, middle managers seem very poorly trained, no support for employees who are bullied by management

review_title: Gone to hell in a hand-basket
pros: The only teaching hospital in our region with some of the best health care providers.
cons: Management. There are more chiefs than Indians. They encourage employees to further their education (to climb the ladder of success). Once employees get their degree, they are offered management positions. With the shift in healthcare reform, you cannot afford to pay these power-hungry folks. Instead of thinning the heard of department heads, they go on witch hunts and push out  the employees beneath them. They go after employees who have been there the longest (so that they can hire new people and pay them a fraction of the wages).What once was a wonderful place to work, has become a money hungry corporation.

pros:
Compensation and benefits package attractive
Several locations available
cons: Revolving door for a reason, across all locations.  Low morale, high turnover. Found middle management to be either combative or unresponsive, depending on the person.   I expected more from this organization, which promises to be supportive and encouraging but operates in just the opposite manner.  Truly disappointing experience.

review_title: Unsupported clinical work and not as advertised
pros: Medical students are great. Wonderful physician and NP and PA colleagues. Location.
cons: Disparate working conditions for medical student versus resident faculty. Offered things during interview and contract discussion that were later not given. Broke contract and ended research funding after one year instead of two. Retaliatory management. Pressure from managers to prescribe controlled substances that were not safe and not indicated. Disorganized safety and health oversight. Barely any nursing support and physicians manage online messages and lab letters and calls for hours unpaid every week. Call - about 40 calls/day with 3 minutes to return them. Major turnover. Not sustainable full time, and the area is too expensive for part time work.

review_title: Although I disliked my job, the people and facilities were excellent.
pros:
Excellent doctors and nurses.
Beautiful facilities.
Free Parking
Resident salary above average.
cons: Poor overnight/weekend test availability, especially MRIs.  They have to call in a technician from home, which they only do in emergencies.  But what if you're not sure it's an emergency?  Then you have to try to convince a radiologist to call in the technician.  If you don't call in the technician and it turns out that it was an emergency, get ready to talk to a lawyer.

review_title: Extremely sad to see a place that used to be top notch falling very far to the bottom of the scale
job_title: Critical Care Nurse in Lebanon, NH
pros: Good reputation; Excellent staff to work with aside from management, Physicians are top of the line, caring, willing to work with and respect other staff, all staff from physicians to nurse aides to transport and other ancillary services work well together, aside from management. If it wasn't for the amazing and talented physicians there and supportive nature of many staff members, I would only give it 1 star.
cons: Absolutely horrible management/administration/human resources. Very poor standards, loss of quality in work/care which used to be at the top of their list and is one of the biggest contributors to their loss of magnet status. I was told that "Dartmouth doesn't like people who speak up... Dartmouth doesn't like people who ask questions... Dartmouth only likes people who shut up and just do whatever they want and don't make suggestions or stray from the norm...", this is not acceptable in critical care nursing, especially in a teaching facility. Promotes within which does not work in this environment.

review_title: Ok place to work, not as great as it once was.
pros: Decent pay and benefits. Most other employees are decent with one another. But still a larger employer.
cons: Environment, seem to have money to pay for new VP's, and directors of new programs but in the same breath out source 350 jobs in 2 departments to save money, these employees will not have the same benefits as they did have as a hospital employee.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Bedford, NH
pros: The train you for at least a month before having you on your own.
cons: If can get frustrating if you are not quick enough.  The team lead only likes to help you if it is necessary.  They expect you to be able to handle yourself by yourself only after a week of training.

review_title: Did You Like Junior High School ?
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in West Lebanon, NH
pros:
If you didn’t love the mean girls and the bullies and the tattletales and the back-stabbers and the cliques and the immaturity way back when . . . 

THEN RUN AWAY !!!

The only reasons to work at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center are:
1. If you live really close by;
2. You have absolutely no other option;
3. You have a high tolerance for idiocy;
4. You operate just like them.

Or maybe you are looking for experience or a short term situation.  DHMC is DEFINITELY NOT a happy career move.


	First off, before my review, really examine the other reviews on this site or other sites.  A good number of the positive reviews I’ve read are not from medical staff. Some are from IT, and I  know that IT is just as much of a mess as the rest of the place.  More positive reviews are coming from management themselves.  In other cases I would not at all be surprised if management  threatened people if they did not submit positive reviews. Yes, some of management is that underhanded and dishonest. Just like on any site where you are trying to decide to buy something, look for detail, look for the department, which job, for how long, etc..  No doubt there have to be some employees who have had a good experience (if you can find them) so see if there are openings where they worked.  Likely those get filled in-house fast. The best bet is to talk to actual employees. Really make the effort, really take the time. Listen between the lines. Go there from 3 to 4 PM and talk to people going into work and those leaving. (Across from the ER entrance is a good spot.) This will be your life so invest the time. And for goodness sake, don’t even consider moving to the area for a job at DHMC !  Living close by is expensive, a lot of people commute 45 min to 2+ hours EACH WAY !!! But mostly, the place has a lot of toxicity, and not just from pathogens and cleaning products.

	I’m not one for bad-mouthing places, restaurants, hotels, certainly not a place where I spent a lot of time making things work and helping a lot of patients (most of the last 20 years), but an aspect of Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center that I was aware of but had not affected me personally jumped out of management’s abattoir and sunk it’s meat hooks in me.

	It’s too bad, the place could be a good place to work, some really great people. But that is WAYYYYYYY off in the future.

The salient points:

DO NOT WORK IN GOOD FAITH AT DARTMOUTH-HITCHCOCK !!!  GET EVERYTHING IN WRITING !

The employee model at DHMC is based on the indentured servitude model, a fear and subservience approach. Gotta shop at the company store. They want you to need your job, and they want you to live in fear of your job. Most people who work there NEED the money, the insurance and benefits, DHMC likes it that way and they use it against you.

Working from home ? . . . FAGETABOUTIT !!! Even though the CEO herself endorses it there is a crackdown by management to keep people from working from home.  Doesn’t matter if you’ve been doing it for 2 years, 6 years, 18 years and have never had a complaint, getting a lot of work done when it comes in, not now !  You will have to sign a “Work at Home” contract, submit to a “workplace compatibility” inspection, unannounced pop-in inspections AND be required to have childcare while you are there working at home !      What’s the point ! A lot of people working from home do it to save on childcare which they could not afford if they worked in-house 5 days a week. Childcare is expensive !!!  Other people, particularly researchers often have sponsors that are in Europe, different time zones, different holidays. Samples are shipped to those places and sometimes they go missing. More often, changes in protocol or official documentation come in other than standard work hours. 

An early rising nurse I talked to is prevented from answering early bird communications from patients from home to triage and clear the cue a couple hours before getting to work for some dumb reason.  “I know the patients are up because the just “emailed” me !” she explained.

First rate institutions listen to their people, get feedback and institute changes.  DHMC doesn’t. They tell you what to do.  Even if they’ve never done it.  Especially if they’ve never done it ? . . .

DHMC makes the mistake of believing its own PR.

The current situation in research is a disaster. 

The new research paradigm from another institution is being hammered into place without the input of those who have been doing research there for decades.

People who don’t have the capacity to do your job, and don’t even understand your job will be telling you how to do your job, and when to do your job, and where to do your job, NOT at home.

Don’t expect to get support from your docs, they are either too afraid to stand up to 30-somethings with BA’s, or don’t have the authority somehow. (Really, I don’t know how some of these managers got hired, what they did to get hired, or what they had claimed to have done to get hired. They are really horrible, not just as managers but as people. Ask around.)

11 months and counting for two separate research professionals who are being harassed and targeted for removal.  Both do unimpeachable work and bring in lots of $$$$$. What’s the problem ?  Somehow their respective docs with all of their experience and degrees have no say.

When you are removed or forced out or “resigned” your former colleagues including doctors will be told by management not to have any contact with you (Yes. That is true !), and they will obey, most of them. (See: Fear and subservience above.)

DHMC cares about money, their money not yours. 

DHMC is vastly understaffed which means that if you are a worker you will get other jobs piled on you.

Overtime is being scrutinized at this point since the place is underwater. That means some of the staff who are doing multiple jobs will being working and not putting in for it for fear of their jobs.  

DHMC will loudly proclaim that their employees should be compensated for all the work they do and the time they accrue but you could likely be doing the work of at least another half person if not two. You may also have to hire a lawyer to make sure you get all the compensation you are due. I know people who have had to hire lawyers to get their due despite their decades at DHMC, superlative workers and performers, not troublemakers as DHMC will claim.

DHMC being vastly understaffed hires managers who get rid of people, good people. That doesn’t make any sense, business or otherwise. They find the least resourceful people who are marginally qualified, put them through some sort of narrow, gulag training and let them loose. Clear examples of people rising to the level of their incompetence. The worst part is that higher management backs these people without even listening to the concerns of those who are torpedoed.

DHMC is not even close to being a second rate institution. The way it is going now it is quickly sliding into a fourth rate institution.  Talk to people who have worked in the Boston hospitals.

Most of the docs are dedicated and good (though there are some departments I will not use) but the lack of staff is making things increasingly harder to provide good patient care.  Patient care is suffering, patients are leaving, seeking other facilities. Management knows this yet continues to get rid of highly productive professionals and staffs based on “assessments” and “evaluations” (lies ? . . .) of some managers. Know any super pro nurse who was fired for “going above and beyond” ?  I do !

Games are being played by these managers.  Imagine asking to see your latest quarterly evaluation,  your evaluation which an employee is entitled to see and being told, “These aren’t for you, they’re for me.”  WRONG ! How is an employee supposed to improve ? Power-tripping, that’s all it is.

Not all departments are horrible to work for, but a lot are. Providers purse their lips and make no comment. Providers know that patient care is suffering due to management.

Co-workers who don’t play nice and make others in the unit hate to be around them, and as a result, dislike a job they would otherwise enjoy, don’t get fired. People who go above and beyond get fired or forced out. It’s like some weird opposite world over there.

Do not go above and beyond !  That will count against you. Do get everything in writing. You cannot trust DHMC management. They are NOT looking out for your benefit. Lawsuits are the only thing that management understands.

There will be growing pains when a new system is being implemented, understood. But why force changes on research that is already being done by super-pro researchers with superlative results ? Does not make sense.  Why destroy existing research ?  Why not get the system going with new research projects ? Ease it in, work out the kinks instead of ruining patients samples.  This speaks to the level of competency of management.

If you plan on getting into research at DHMC, reconsider. If you plan on doing research in the department of Medicine then you are masochistic or otherwise mentally ill. (You will likely not be the only one.)  Talk to the people there.

The way a lot of people are treated at DHMC is so bad, so beyond the normal, rational, human mind that if this were a book you would put it down because it is too unbelievable.

Nursing is the most respected profession in the country, except at DHMC.

Research is not the only area with this metastasizing cancer . . .



What I’ve have heard recently:

“If you are willing to fire people you will move ahead in management.”  From a retired health care professional (HCP) with 30+ years at DHMC.

“Who does she think she is !?!” An HCP with 30+ years of varied experience (from whose mouth I’ve never heard a cross word let alone a bad one) about a new manager who seems perversely bent on destroying the work professionals have been doing for decades. Work which brings in significant money and increases DHMC’s reputation.  Upper management definitely doesn’t care.  Is this how they are training management ?

“That department is a cesspool.”  HCP with 40 years of varied experience hoping to last a few more years to retirement without getting fired like other HCP’s this person has worked with.

“DHMC is a disaster. It is getting impossible to do good research here.” Research professional who has worked in top research facilities in major cities and other parts of the country and could be making triple the money if she wanted to move back.

“The way DHMC treats its people it deserves whatever it gets.” An HCP with decades of patient care and treatment, and decades in research.

“In the Boston hospitals where I worked the nurses were listened to. Our opinions and suggestions were valued. In fact, we were regarded just the same as the docs, no separation. That doesn’t happen here.”  HCP with 3+ decades of varied experience in Boston who is not being utilized or listened to at DHMC.

“The devices used to be downloaded and the readout given to me prior to my appointments.  Now I have to go to the secretary to to get it downloaded. This takes a big chunk out of my time with my patients.”  HCP specialist who is being hamstrung by lack of staff. Oh, the person who used to do the downloads as well as a whole bunch of other highly necessary things is gone despite warning management that things are not going well for her is gone. She used to be able to do a device training when asked by a doc THAT DAY.  The wait for getting a training is now 3-4 months.

This is what dedicated HCP’s at DHMC talk about. I have never, ever once heard any person I know who works or worked at DHMC come close to saying (and with 20 years of association, I know people . . .), ‘What a day I just had at work ! I love my job at DHMC .’  Come to think of it, I may have been the closest to saying that . . . Then the new management showed up . . .

17 years combined, lean, light, part time and cheap, bringing in lots of money for DHMC, the job we did could not have been done better, you think we would be lauded, at least a “thank you”. That team is gone ! I have not heard one word from any of the former team members - Principle Investigator, Sub-investigators. That’s how much you will be valued and appreciated by DHMC. The study I had ready to go last summer has started . . . technically . . . But no patients. DHMC is out hundreds of thousands of dollars (if not multiples more) with a significant hit to their research reputation. Upper management supported the decision to get rid of us. You have been warned.
cons:
Management: 

At any institution management should be there to work out the kinks, the “paper jams”, the “800 pound, rabid gorilla” problems to keep things running as smoothly as possible.  Not at DHMC. Too many managers act like their unit is their little fiefdom and their word is law, even if they were in junior high school when you were doing outstanding work there.  Why make things harder for people ? . . . Oh, that’s right, ego . . . 

Consider yourself lucky if you simply get a competent manager, let alone a good one.

Your actual performance does NOT matter, only what you “supervisor” says your performance is matters, even if he or she has never even seen you work, OR even understands your work. The assessments of you colleagues, docs, and co-workers doesn’t matter.

It does not matter if you have done decades of superlative work, qualitatively and quantitatively, bringing in a lot of money, no complaints or disciplinary issues, get along with everyone, if some 30-something with a BA wants you out, you are out ! They will be backed up by other management (all the way up . . .) most of whom do not understand what you do They don’t care about the loss of hundreds of thousands of dollars to the institution. They don’t care about the deep hit to DHMC’s research reputation.  All that matters to these people is, “WHAT I SAY GOES ! PERIOD !!! “  And they will be backed up.

Some of the managers in charge of research have no business even talking to actual human beings let alone lording it over professionals. A good number of these people are making nurse practitioner money ($90K+) and do not understand what research entails, and some are gone by 3:30 every afternoon. A former unit manager I knew used to be there till 7 PM to keep things running as smoothly as possible.  She’s gone now.

HR is simply a tentacle of management used to gather information against you. HR is NOT on your side.  This comes from people with decades of service to DHMC before my own experience with HR.

Imagine having your manager tell a health care professional (HCP) that the long distance trip put in for at least 6 months prior, already bought and paid for, could not be taken because the manager had not found a replacement yet. That was a week before the trip. How’s that for building morale ?

Imagine a manager telling an HCP the week before the person’s wedding 1000 miles away that that person could not go to their own wedding because that person had not found their own replacement yet. That’s management’s job.  Again, morale ? . . .

That manager is still there. Management has the time to harass and torpedo staff but does not seem to have the time to do some of the really important actual managerial tasks. Pitching in when it is busy ?? Not these people.

Do not go above and beyond !  That will count against you. Do get everything in writing. You cannot trust DHMC management. They are NOT looking out for your benefit. Lawsuits are the only thing that management understands.

pros: EMR is user friendly. they have some wonderful support staff
cons: Dartmouth has absolutely no interest in retaining good, quality people;  It is a revolving door of employees: I have had 3 nurses in less than 2 years and have waited 4 mos for the hiring of a new MA. There has been an exodus of excellent physicians and mid levels in the last few years and Dartmouth does not seem to care.Their philosophy seems to be "its our way or the highway" and there is no room for discussion. I have had patients who have gone through 5 PCPs in the last 3-4 years but this doesn't seem to phase Dartmouth. During the hiring process they promise docs wonderful things to maximize efficiency such as having patients scheduled 15 min earlier than their appointments, daily huddles to look for bugs in schedule, autonomy over one's practice, late and no show policies; then once hired, docs discover none of these actually happen.  They don't seem to get it that the doctors are the money makers for them and if they would concentrate on the issues that made the docs lives easier, not only would the doctors be happier but we could also see more patients.  Middle management is completely oblivious to the issues that need fixing in the clinic setting,and when employees attempt to address issues, they are labeled as " complainers" and essentially told to suck it up. There is absolutely no support for doctors.  The scheduling of patients is an absolute nightmare with the philosophy being- stick patients in anywhere regardless of their issues-they have a protocol for visits based on their complaint but they never follow it and any complaints about this fall on deaf ears so docs are forced to address more issues in inadequate time which leads to poor patient care.

job_title: Can't Say They Like to Retaliate in Lebanon, NH
pros: A beautiful building on a beautiful campus (on the outside). Many perks in-house: banking, travel agency, hair salon, many food options, post office. Great libraries and resources.
cons: This is the most toxic environment I have ever worked in, with poor leadership and many layers of "fluff" that are just putting in their time until retirement.  It's no wonder they are not getting Magnet designation again....one look at the nursing and patient satisfaction rates and the surveyors were alarmed. They are sadly not alone. as most staff is miserable and feel trapped into working there as there are not many other options in the area.  Employees are expected to drink the Dartmouth Kool-Aid, and when they don't, they are "counseled" about not being a team player and made to feel small and ind=significant and replaceable.  You are not allowed to advocate for staff or patients, and there are many MANY medical errors made in the facility daily, all covered up and never mentioned except in whispers in offices and meeting rooms. As a nursing leader, I was chastised for standing up for staff and patients. Many leaders with tenure take advantage of their position by coming in late, leaving early, going to workout for an hour during the day, leaving to run personal errands, or just taking hour long walks outside on nice days...all while hell is breaking loose inside the facility. Staff work in fear of losing their jobs instead of being encouraged to share ideas to make work better. The majority of computer platforms do not work well with each other, leaving employees frustrated and patients open for errors to occur.  This severe lack of communication starts at the top....I NEVER saw or met the CEO or CNO...those people you see in the newsletter touting themselves to be on the front lines with us. Forget it! They are locked up in their office or on "business trips" promoting themselves. In short...the employees make THEM look good.And forget taking your concerns to HR, they are as nonchalant about the corruption as Senior Leadership.  How hard is it to know that your employees want to be recognized and appreciated and in turn will give you 110%? It's not rocket science....be visible, be appreciative, and know when to step up and help. Don't act like you are doing them a favor by letting them work there. Some staff are choosing less money at smaller facilities just to get away from the insanity. And patients are choosing smaller community hospitals where they are treated like people, not experiments or numbers.  I would never seek care here for myself or my family. Check their sepsis rates prior to 2014, look at their HCAPS scores....Dartmouth Hitchcock just doesn't deliver the stellar care they say they do.  They have their share of cleanliness issues: bedbugs, lice, ants...they don't even isolate MRSA patients, so a perfectly non-infected person could be sharing a room and bathroom with someone with active MRSA.  I must have heard 100 times, "We don't have to worry about patients coming here, where else are they going to go?" Well guess what, DHMC, they are going in DROVES to Boston and other places that are better managed, with better patient outcomes and happier staff. Maybe one day you will see that being the biggest does not guarantee you designation as the best.

pros:
Wonderful talented doctors that are highly regarded in their field.  Nurses and support staff take pride in their work and how they care for patients.  The main medical center in Lebanon is a beautiful building, well appointed in a way that makes patients and visitors feel welcome and supported.  Waiting rooms/areas are spacious, clean and comfortable. Halls and corridors are cheerful (without being obnoxious). There are many convenient nooks with comfortable seating that provide semi-private areas for families to decompress, away from higher populated/trafficked areas. A cancer center that is absolutely amazing.

I am relatively satisfied with my position and the work I do.  If someone I knew was considering a job at DHMC, I would have to say their satisfaction will depend on the position and the managment they will work under. If applying for a management position, I would think twice.
cons: Let's start at the top: CEO - seems more focused on forcing fluffy delusional marketing gimmicks on the entire organization instead of working with other "chiefs" on the fifth floor actually creating the "Sustainable Health System" we hear so much about.  Communication consists of latest buzz phrases and focus is to be the leader or innovator in the next big thing. Somewhat like a crow chasing anything that shines. Very disconnect organizational hierarchy. The other Chief level executives are not a united leadership group, they're all fighting for position and favor.  They withhold resources and information from one another and from their respective parts of the organization for fear of losing one of their pieces in the "game" or the possibility one of the others will get ahead. Leaders that don't align with JW, (or God forbid publically disagree) don't stay around.  Absolutely NONE of this improves patient care!!! It's all about stroking their ego's and squashing those that disagree. Bloated ego's and salaries that drain the institution and prevent it from being the absolute best in the region.
